member.name: T:Fove.Compositor
member.summary: This class is a wrapper around the C API's Fove_Compositor. It is the main way to draw content to a headset.

member.name: M:Fove.Compositor.Finalize
member.summary: Dispose native resources and destroy the compositor wrapper

member.name: M:Fove.Compositor.CreateLayer(Fove.CompositorLayerCreateInfo,Fove.CompositorLayer@)
member.summary:
Creates a new layer within the compositor
This function create a layer upon which frames may be submitted to the compositor by this client.
A connection to the compositor must exists for this to pass. This means you need to wait for fove_Compositor_isReady before calling this function. However, if connection to the compositor is lost and regained, this layer will persist. For this reason, you should not recreate your layers upon reconnection, simply create them once.
There is no way to delete a layer once created, other than to destroy the Fove_Compositor object. This is a feature we would like to add in the future.
member.param: The settings for the layer to be created
A struct where the defaults of the newly created layer will be written
member.returns: on success. The corresponding error code otherwise

member.name: M:Fove.Compositor.Submit(Fove.CompositorLayerSubmitInfo@)
member.summary:
Submit a frame to the compositor.
This function takes the feed from your game engine to the compositor for output.
member.param: Layer information for the layer to submit
member.returns: on success. The corresponding error code otherwise

member.name: M:Fove.Compositor.WaitForRenderPose(Fove.Pose@)
member.summary:
Wait for the most recent pose for rendering purposes.
All compositor clients should use this function as the sole means of limiting their frame rate. This allows the client to render at the correct frame rate for the HMD display. Upon this function returning, the client should proceed directly to rendering, to reduce the chance of missing the frame. If outPose is not null, this function will return the latest pose as a convenience to the caller.
member.example:
In general, a client's main loop should look like:
Update(); // Run AI, physics, etc, for the next frame compositor.WaitForRenderPose(out pose); // Wait for the next frame, and get the pose Draw(pose); // Render the scene using the new pose
member.param: The latest pose of the headset.
member.returns: on success. The corresponding error code otherwise

member.name: M:Fove.Compositor.GetLastRenderPose(Fove.Pose@)
member.summary: Get the last cached pose for rendering purposes
member.param: The last cached pose
member.returns: on success. The corresponding error code otherwise

member.name: M:Fove.Compositor.IsReady
member.summary: Get the ready state of the compositor
member.returns: True if we are connected to a running compositor and ready to submit frames for compositing

member.name: M:Fove.Compositor.GetAdapterId(Fove.AdapterId@)
member.summary:
Returns the ID of the GPU currently attached to the headset
For systems with multiple GPUs, submitted textures to the compositor must from the same GPU that the compositor is using
member.param: The ID of the adapter
member.returns: True if we are connected to a running compositor and ready to submit frames for compositing

member.summary: Destroy native compositor

member.name: T:Fove.ClientCapabilities
member.summary:
List of capabilities usable by clients
Most features require registering for the relevant capability. If a client queries data related to a capability it has not registered API_NotRegistered will be returned.
This enum is designed to be used as a flag set, so items may be binary logic operators like |.
The FOVE runtime will keep any given set of hardware/software running so long as one client is registering a capability.
The registration of a capability does not necessarily mean that the capability is running. For example, if no position tracking camera is attached, no position tracking will occur regardless of how many clients registered for it.

member.name: T:Fove.HeadsetHardwareInfo
member.summary:
Struct Contains hardware information for the headset
Contains the serial number, manufacturer and model name for the headset. Values of the member fields originates from their UTF-8 string representations defined by headset manufacturers, and passed to us (FoveClient) by FoveService server through an IPC message. The server may be sending very long strings, but the FoveClient library will be truncating them in an unspecified manner to 0-terminated strings of length at most 256.

member.summary: Native collider mesh structure

member.name: F:Fove.ObjectCollider.ColliderMesh.vertices
member.summary:
The vertices of the mesh
It contains the X, Y, Z positions of mesh vertices. Triangles are defined using "indices".

member.name: F:Fove.ObjectCollider.ColliderMesh.vertexCount
member.summary:
The number of element in the vertex buffer
Note that one vertex has three component (X, Y, Z). So the size of vertices array is `3 x vertexCount`.

member.name: F:Fove.ObjectCollider.ColliderMesh.indices
member.summary:
The vertex indices defining the triangles of the mesh
Triangles are listed one after the others (and not combined using a fan or strip algorithm). The number of elements must equal `3 x triangleCount`.
Outward faces are defined to be specified counter-clockwise. Face-direction information is not currently used but may be in the future.
If null, the vertices are interpreted as a simple triangle list.

member.name: F:Fove.ObjectCollider.ColliderMesh.triangleCount
member.summary: The number of triangle present in the mesh

member.summary: The bounding box of the mesh collider
member.remarks: If null the bounding box is re-calculated internally

member.name: T:Fove.MeshColliderBase`2
member.summary:
Generic base class for a mesh collider
A mesh collider can either be defined through a triangle list or through a vertex/index buffer set. If the index buffer pointer is null, then the vertex buffer is interpreted as a regular triangle list.
member.typeparam: The type to use for the vertex array
The type to use for the index array

member.name: F:Fove.MeshColliderBase`2.vertices
member.summary:
The vertices of the mesh
It contains the X, Y, Z positions of mesh vertices. The length of the array should be a multiple of 3. Triangles are defined using "indices".

member.name: F:Fove.MeshColliderBase`2.indices
member.summary:
The vertex indices defining the triangles of the mesh
Triangles are listed one after the others (and not combined using a fan or strip algorithm). The number of elements must multiple of `3`.
Outward faces are defined to be specified counter-clockwise. Face-direction information is not currently used but may be in the future.
If null, the vertices are interpreted as a simple triangle list.

member.name: P:Fove.EyeShape.Outline
member.summary:
Return the eye outline, it is composed of 12 points as follow:
Point 0: the inside extremity of the outline (the point the closest to the nose)
Point 1 to 5: bottom eyelid points going from the inside to the outside of the eye
Point 6: the outside extremity of the outline (the point the furthest from the nose)
Point 7 to 11: top eyelid points going from the outside to the inside of the eye

member.name: T:Fove.CalibrationState
member.summary:
Indicate the state of a calibration process
A calibration process always starts from the `NotStarted` state, then it can go back and forth between the `WaitingForUser` and `CollectingData` states, then it goes to the `ProcessingData` state and finishes with the `Successful` state.
A failure can happen any time during the process, and stops the process where it was.
From the `ProcessingData` state the calibration process do not require any rendering and gameplay can be started if wanted but new calibration won't be effective before reaching the `Successful` state.

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.NotStarted
member.summary: No calibration process haven't been started yet

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.HeadsetAdjustment
member.summary: The calibration process is waiting for the user to adjust the headset

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.WaitingForUser
member.summary: The calibration process is waiting for the user to get ready

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.CollectingData
member.summary: The calibration process is currently collecting calibration data

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.ProcessingData
member.summary: The calibration process is currently processing the collected data

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Successful_HighQuality
member.summary: The calibration is successful and of high quality

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Successful_MediumQuality
member.summary: The calibration is successful and of medium quality

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Successful_LowQuality
member.summary: The calibration is successful but of low quality

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Failed_Unknown
member.summary: The calibration process failed due to an unknown issue

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Failed_InaccurateData
member.summary: The calibration process failed because of inaccurate or flawed data

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Failed_NoRenderer
member.summary: The calibration process failed after timeout because it couldn't find a renderer

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Failed_NoUser
member.summary: The calibration process failed after timeout because it couldn't detect the user

member.name: F:Fove.CalibrationState.Failed_Aborted
member.summary: The calibration process was manually aborted by the user

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.WaitAndFetchNextEyeTrackingData
member.summary:
Waits for next eye camera frame to be processed and fetch the updated eye tracking data
Allows you to sync your eye tracking loop to the actual eye-camera loop. On each loop, you would first call this blocking function to wait for a new frame and then read the eye tracking info associated with the frame.
member.remarks: Eye tracking should be enabled by registering the before calling this function.
member.returns:
The latest eye frame timestamp, and the call success status:
on success
if not connected to the service
if the required capability has not been registered prior to this call

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.FetchEyeTrackingData
member.summary:
Fetch the latest eye tracking related data from runtime service
This function is never blocking, if the data is already up-to-date no operation is performed. It outputs the timestamp of the new gaze information.This can be used to know if data has been updated or not.
member.remarks: Eye tracking should be enabled by registering the before calling this function.
member.returns:
The latest eye frame timestamp, and the call success status:
on success
if not connected to the service
if the required capability has not been registered prior to this call

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.GetGazeScreenPosition(Fove.Eye)
member.summary:
Returns the user's 2D gaze position on the screens seen through the HMD's lenses
The use of lenses and distortion correction creates a screen in front of each eye. This function returns 2D vectors representing where on each eye's screen the user is looking.
The vectors are normalized in the range [-1, 1] along both X and Y axes such that the following points are true. Center: (0, 0), Bottom-Left: (-1, -1),Top-Right: (1, 1).
member.remarks: should be registered to use this function.
member.param: Specify which eye to get the value for
member.returns:

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.TickEyeTrackingCalibration(System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Tick the current calibration process and retrieve data information to render the current calibration state.
This function is how the client declares to the calibration system that is available to render calibration. The calibration system determines which of the available renderers has the highest priority, and returns to that render the information needed to render calibration via the outTarget parameter. Even while ticking this, you may get no result because either no calibration is running, or a calibration is running but some other higher priority renderer is doing the rendering.
It is perfectly fine not to call this function, in which case the Fove service will automatically render the calibration process for you.

remarks.remarks: should be registered to use this function.

member.param: The time elapsed since the last rendered frame

Indicate to the calibration system that something is being drawn to the screen. This allows the calibration renderer to take as much time as it wants to display success/failure messages and animate away before the calibration processes is marked as completed by the `IsEyeTrackingCalibrating` function.
member.returns:
The current calibration data, and the call success status:
on success.
if not connected to the service
if the required capability has not been registered prior to this call
if another process has currently the priority for rendering calibration process
if you don't have the license level required to access this feature

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.RegisterGazableObject(Fove.GazableObject)
member.summary:
Registers an object in the 3D world
Registering 3D world objects allows FOVE software to identify which objects are being gazed at. We recommend that clients opt-in to this functionality rather than doing it themselves, as our algorithm may improve over time. Clients of course may do their own detection if they have special needs, such as performance needs, or just want to use their own algorithm.
member.remarks: Connection to the service is not required for object registration, thus you can register your world objects at will and not worry about connection or reconnection status
member.param: A description of the object in the 3D world. Data is copied and no reference is kept to this memory after return

list.item: on success.
if the object is invalid in any way (such as an invalid object id).
if an object with same id is already registered

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.RegisterCameraObject(Fove.CameraObject)
member.summary:
Registers an camera in the 3D world
Registering 3D world objects and camera allows FOVE software to identify which objects are being gazed at. We recommend that clients opt-in to this functionality rather than doing it themselves, as our algorithm may improve over time. Clients of course may do their own detection if they have special needs, such as performance needs, or just want to use their own algorithm.
At least 1 camera needs to be registered for automatic object gaze recognition to work. Use the object group mask of the camera to specify which objects the camera is capturing. The camera view pose determine the gaze raycast direction and position. The camera view pose should include any and all offsets from position tracking. No transforms from the headset are added in automatically.
member.remarks: Connection to the service is not required for object registration, thus you can register your world objects at will and not worry about connection or reconnection status.
member.param: A description of the camera. Data is copied and no reference is kept to this memory after return.

list.item: on success.
if the object is invalid in any way (such as an invalid object id).
if an object with same id is already registered.

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.GetRenderIOD
member.summary:
Interocular distance to use for rendering in meters
This is an estimation of the distance between centers of the left and right eyeballs. Half of the IOD can be used to displace the left and right cameras for stereoscopic rendering. We recommend calling this each frame when doing stereoscopic rendering. Future versions of the FOVE service may update the IOD during runtime as needed.
member.returns:
A floating point value describing the IOD, and the call success status:
on success

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.CreateProfile(System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a new profile
The FOVE system keeps a set of profiles so that different users on the same system can store data, such as calibrations, separately. Profiles persist to disk and survive restart. Third party applications can control the profile system and store data within it.
member.remarks: This function creates a new profile, but does not add any data or switch to it.
member.param: Unique name of the profile to create

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.GetProfileDataPath(System.String)
member.summary:
Gets the data folder for a given profile
Allows you to retrieve a filesytem directory where third party apps can write data associated with this profile. This directory will be created before return.
Since multiple applications may write stuff to a profile, please prefix any files you create with something unique to your application.
There are no special protections on profile data, and it may be accessible to any other app on the system. Do not write sensitive data here.
This is intended for simple uses. For advanced uses that have security concerns, or want to sync to a server, etc, third party applications are encouraged to use their own separate data store keyed by profile name. They will need to test for profile name changes and deletions manually in that case.
member.remarks: Please note that no-ops are OK but you should check for .
member.param: The name of the profile to be queried, or an empty string if no profile is set
member.returns:
The data path associated to the provided profile, and the call success status:
if the data path was successfully created and returned
if there is no such profile
if not connected to the service
if the requested profile is the current profile
if profileName is null

member.name: M:Fove.Headset.CreateCompositor
member.summary:
Returns a compositor interface from the given headset
Each call to this function creates a new object. The object should be destroyed with fove_Compositor_destroy It is fine to call this function multiple times with the same headset, the same pointer will be returned. It is ok for the compositor to outlive the headset passed in.
member.returns: The compositor instance
member.exception: When the creation of compositor failed
